blindness and so the current guidelines of care say that the patients should be

with UTIs so that's the question and we said all right can we answer this so we did
this whole process and then first we tested four known associations so that
we could convince ourselves that we're not just seeing random noise here so if your arthritis starts in less than four
joints which is what it means to be oo articular onset that is known to increase your
risk being positive for anti-nuclear antibodies increases your risk being
positive for RF factor or rheumatoid factor is protective and having a history or family history of psorisis
increases your risk these are all known things and so we reproduced them to convince ourselves that this kind of
data mining is in fact possible and then we tested the question that the uh the
parent of a patient had and we are using allergies and allergy medications as
sget for each other because uh the Assumption being you wouldn't be taking an allergy med unless you have allergies
and turns out the answer that we were able to get out of the uh data mining is

Uvis and so if you wanted to do this at your own institution you this slide that

diseases devices procedures then how are you going to map

in the example of a beta blocker and then the fourth question is at what level do you stop because at the

note you have drugs disease procedures device which is not that useful and figuring out the right level is is an
important question uh important decision to make in the analysis so to make this
uh these four decisions the way we approach them is to start out with lots
of unstructured data what you're seeing is a screenshot of a fake clinical document that input text goes into a
text processing engine which reads in in its processing something we call a
knowledge graph which corresponds to uh the correspondence between the different
kinds of entities you can have and so on along with that you feed in some ways of
detecting negation because a lot of medical writing involves things like no evidence of hypertension or no uh no
sign of so and so and so in the knowledge graph not only do
you get the correspondence between things and and the hierarchy we also have a lot of additional information of
the form how often is a particular term such as acute myocard farction the whole
thing mentioned across the records of millions of people so think of that as some version of term frequency and
inverse document frequency we also calculate how often is
a particular phrase a noun or an adjective or an adverb and so on
and most diseases I know of are nouns and so if your particular text phrase you're looking as is not a noun you
don't have to worry about it being a disease for the most part and then the third thing we do is we ask how crazy or
confusing a term is so something like cell c l l is very confusing because it
could mean a cell phone it could mean a terrorist cell it could mean the cell in a Petra dish we we try to avoid those
kinds of terms but something like acute myocard infarction is kind of straightforward it only means one thing
it couldn't be somebody's name and so all of this goes in and out
comes an index where what's really stored is just the blue portion which is just a bunch of integers and numbers and
uh the the the other portion is just a human readable Visual and the main take home is that everything that is not a
medical thing becomes white space only Medical words are preserved and the
things that were negated are shown in Red so that's sort of the takeaway from that picture and then what we
avoid is that at this analysis this processing time we do not try to bind
the term to a concept and what I mean by that is if I see stroke St Str r o k we
don't try to determine add the indexing time that is it heat stroke heart stroke or cerebrovascular stroke or Stroke of

say we will defer that decision till we absolutely need to make that
determination and there's some advantages of doing that because when at analysis time in the 500 patients or a

I mean we can start using the experiences of other people who are
